componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Ashley, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Sales Fiscal Q4 2016 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. And I would now like to turn the call over to
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Ashley, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Sales Fiscal Q4 2016 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. And I would now like to turn the call over to our host, Mr. John Cummings. Sir, you may begin your conference.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks so much, Ashley. Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us for our fiscal fourth quarter and full year 2016 results conference call. Our fourth quarter results press release, SEC filings and a replay of today's call can be found on our IR
componenttext:
Thanks so much, Ashley. Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us for our fiscal fourth quarter and full year 2016 results conference call. Our fourth quarter results press release, SEC filings and a replay of today's call can be found on our IR website at www.salesforce.com/investor.
With me on the call today is Marc Benioff, Chairman and CEO; Keith Block, Vice Chairman, President and COO; and Mark Hawkins, CFO.
As a reminder, our commentary today will primarily be in non-GAAP terms. Reconciliations between our GAAP and non-GAAP results and guidance can be found in our earnings press release.
Some of our comments today may also contain forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks, uncertainties and assumptions. Should any of these materialize or should any our assumptions prove to be incorrect, actual company results could differ materially from these forward-looking statements. A description of our risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that could affect our financial results are included in our SEC filings, including our most recent report on Forms 10-K and 10-Q.
With that, let me turn the call over to Marc.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, John. And we -- this is our biggest call ever. We've got over 500 people around the world who are dialed into the call. So we know there's a lot of interest in the quarter. And we've made a decision, we're going to put aside the vast majorit
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, John. And we -- this is our biggest call ever. We've got over 500 people around the world who are dialed into the call. So we know there's a lot of interest in the quarter. And we've made a decision, we're going to put aside the vast majority of our script so that we can get into Q&A as fast as possible with you. Look, my #1 thing I want to tell you is this is the absolute best quarter we have ever had. It's been just an incredible quarter, way beyond our expectations. It caps an incredible fiscal year for us. I'm sure that you saw that revenues for the quarter rose to $1.8 billion, and that's up 27%, which is really just amazing. Revenue for the full fiscal year was also 27%, $6.7 billion. So you look at those things and you go, wow, I mean, that's a very fast growth rate for our company of our size and scale. We're top 10 enterprise software company. You all know the growth rates, Microsoft, Oracle, SAP are shrinking a negative growth rates in many cases, and here we are to 27% growth rate in this enterprise applications market. And as you get -- and as Keith gets into it, you're going to hear we believe we are selling more enterprise apps than Oracle or SAP. 
Deferred revenue grew to nearly $4.3 billion, which was up 31%. Quarterly operating cash flow was nearly $460 million, up 38%. That number, of course, exceeded everyone's expectation and took us by surprise as well. And we are really proud of that number, $460 million quarterly operating cash flow in the quarter. 
Full year operating cash flow was $1.6 billion, up 37%. And the dollar value of booked business on and off the balance sheet, $11 billion. That is obviously a huge a number for us, something that we've never had before, and it's really a huge reflection of the amount of business that has been achieved in the fiscal year and specifically, in the quarter as well. 
We've got great momentum going into our first quarter. We're guiding to an incredible number here. And $1.895 billion at the high end of our range. And for the full year, we're increasing our revenue guidance to $8.12 billion. So we are really excited and aggressive in our guidance. And it's a -- look, it was an amazing quarter. It was an amazing year. We are confident it's going to be an amazing first quarter. And no other enterprise software company of our size and scale is delivering at this level or as excited as we are. And no one else's is as well positioned for the of customer that we are all moving into this forward investor revolution. 
Before I now hand the call now over to Keith, I just want to thank all of our customers and I want to thank all of our partners and I also want to congratulate all 20,000 of our employees on an amazing year. We are deeply, deeply, deeply grateful for everything that you do for us every day. And we don't forget that for one moment, every single day with us at Salesforce with gratitude. And we know that this is a special time, and we're grateful for all the hard work that everyone has put into. Also, I know you were going to want to catch us on our world tour that's coming off and big events are starting next month. You'll see us at in Germany and in Chicago, Boston, Melbourne, Amsterdam. We'll be in Washington D.C. as well, so come to one of our events. And we've got a great new COO here at Salesforce as well. So Keith, congratulations on your promotion. Well done

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Marc.
componenttext: Thank you very much, Marc.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And why don't you tell us about the quarter?
componenttext: And why don't you tell us about the quarter?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. Listen, this was an amazing quarter. Our team really the whole company delivered the best quarter in 19 years in Salesforce. It was a breakthrough quarter. It certainly was a breakthrough year for us and it translated into an amazing results
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. Listen, this was an amazing quarter. Our team really the whole company delivered the best quarter in 19 years in Salesforce. It was a breakthrough quarter. It certainly was a breakthrough year for us and it translated into an amazing results in every region, every industry and really, across companies of all sizes. We signed 2 of the largest deals that I've seen in my career year. I mean, absolutely fantastic. I mean, first, we signed an exciting 9-figure transaction, one of the world's most respected companies. And second, we signed the largest renewal in the history of the company. And listen, they didn't just renew, they also significantly expanded their 9-figure relationship with us in Q4. And we are now their company-wide platform for innovation. I mean, it's really amazing what the team has done and how these customers have embraced us. 
We also drove an all-time high in the number of large transactions this year which is incredible. More than 600 seven-figure plus transaction and a quarter. And I'll tell you, Marc said it, I'll say it again. No one in the enterprise software, no one in enterprise software is developing more strategic relationships right now than Salesforce. 
And you know what, there's no better example of this in Unilever, which is one of the world's greatest consumer package goods companies. It's a great digital transformation story and a significant, significant expansion for us here in Q4. We've been delivering great levels of success with our consumer and marketing teams. We're now working all across business functions. And Unilever plans to bring 95,000 of their employees onto the Salesforce Platform. So that means they are empowering their digital employee strategy to new levels of engagement. 
Now CharlesSchwabb, another great brand is an exciting new relationship for the quarter. They'll be using Salesforce for the entire CRM platform. This is a great example of how ignited industry team had played a pivotal role when important customer. As you all know, Ignite is part of our go-to-market promotion. Also as mentioned in Q1, if you remember, we had told you about our largest Marketing Cloud win ever. Then, we signed an even bigger one in Q3. And in Q4, we did it again. We topped ourselves, and we entered into our largest marketing cloud relationship ever with a large social network. In fact, Marketing Cloud continues the success and increase the number of large Marketing Cloud transactions by more than 60% in the past year. Also one of the largest resellers in the world expanded with us in the quarter and selected Salesforce as their company-wide collaboration platform. And you know what, there are many, many, many stories. These are the some of the world's greatest brands, some of the greatest stories and we continue to deepen our strategic relationships with all of them. I mean, this is great momentum. It's incredible momentum and growth across all of our key industries, in all of our key markets prickle. And I will say again, as Marc did, I'm very, very proud of it intercompany for all of these accomplishments, all our outstanding results are just positive that our strategy is absolutely more than taking hold. I also like to thank our customers and our partners because they are helping us set the standard for this industry. So with that, I'll hand it over to Mark Hawkins.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Keith. We had an incredible financial quarter, so let me start off with some highlights. In addition to the operating cash flow results, Marc mentioned, we continue to drive increased operating leverage. For the full year, we increased our non-GAA
componenttext:
Thanks, Keith. We had an incredible financial quarter, so let me start off with some highlights. In addition to the operating cash flow results, Marc mentioned, we continue to drive increased operating leverage. For the full year, we increased our non-GAAP operating margin by 177 basis points. This is a great result as we continue to grow our top line. Our year-over-year growth was balanced across all of our clouds and all of our regions. Sales Cloud accelerated in the quarter with 12% growth. Service Cloud were 35%, Marketing Cloud grew 31%. And App Cloud in the others grew 43%. In the regions, EMEA grew 32% and APAC continues to accelerate at 26% growth, both in constant currency. We also got off to a great start in Q4, and an early quarter strength translated into strong billings and collections in the quarter and helped drive our cash flow in Q4. It also helped us drive our top line performance in Q4. And when you exclude FX effect, $32 million revenue was up 27% in constant currency. Supporting this great top line growth was our declining attrition rate, which remains below 9%. Our deferred revenue in the quarter reached an all-time high of $4.3 billion. This is up 31% in constant currency when excluding an FX effect of $48 million. We also continue to drive an increase in annual billings in the quarter with 88% of all our subscription and support-related invoices issued with annual terms. This benefit is a year-over-year deferred revenue growth in the quarter by approximately 3 percentage points. 
Moving on to guidance. Coming up a strong Q4, and with our proven business model, we are raising our FY '17 revenue guidance to $8.12 billion at the high end of the range. And we're also finishing FY '17 non-GAAP EPS guidance of $0.99 to $1.01. In context, we expect to deliver 125  to 150 basis points of non-GAAP operating margin improvement in FY '17. And this is just coming off a year where we exceeded the high-end of our FY '16 operating margin guidance. As a result of this, we continue margin expansion. We expect to drive another full year of strong operating cash flow, with year-over-year growth of 23% to 24%. For Q1, we're expecting revenue of $1.885 billion to $1.895 billion, non-GAAP EPS of $0.23 to $0.24, and year-over-year deferred revenue growth of 24% to 25%. 
A quick note in our Q1 guide. As all of you know, FY '17 is a leap year. And given we recognize our revenue on a daily basis, there's an extra day of subscription revenue in the first quarter. This will benefit our first quarter revenue by approximately $20 million that will drive a slightly higher non-GAAP EPS and will reduce our deferred revenue by the corresponding amount. This is simply timing item that has no impact on the full FY '17 fiscal year results, but this will have an impact on your quarterly and full year compares and FY '18. To close, we had an outstanding quarter in the year, and we're well positioned to get another great year in FY '17. And at this time, I'd like to add my thanks to the entire Salesforce team for this great results. With that, I'd like to open up the call for questions.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our growth strategies really built on having a full portfolio of products. I think you know about that in sales, in service, in marketing, in community, in analytics, in apps, in the IoT, and as well as a full portfolio of geographies as well doing
componenttext: Well, our growth strategies really built on having a full portfolio of products. I think you know about that in sales, in service, in marketing, in community, in analytics, in apps, in the IoT, and as well as a full portfolio of geographies as well doing business around the world like in the United States, in Japan, in Europe, Australia and Canada and in addition to doing business with enterprises and as well as small and medium businesses. And when that full portfolio accelerates, that is, they all come in, in the quarter, which we really never expect, every product and every geography, in both enterprise and SMB to come in, then you got this kind of accelerated revenue growth which is what you see is this 27% number of both  year and the quarter. And as I said, in my opening remarks, this is the best quarter we've ever seen. We would never expect to see every product group and every geography and every sector of our business exceed our expectations. So that's what we saw in the fourth quarter. And that creates this phenomenal momentum that we have now. And look at that number on and off the balance sheet, $11 billion. There's no greater predictor of our future success than this deferred revenue that we now have in place.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, and let me pick up the second half of that question that you directed. Just building on Marc's comments, I think you'd ask a little bit about the seasonality in FY '17 starting with Q1. Back at our Analyst Day, Keith is referring to, we looked at t
componenttext: Great, and let me pick up the second half of that question that you directed. Just building on Marc's comments, I think you'd ask a little bit about the seasonality in FY '17 starting with Q1. Back at our Analyst Day, Keith is referring to, we looked at this compounding affect and more of and more of our renewals business happening in showing up in Q4, showing up in DR and then having a quarter-on-quarter effect throughout the year. That compounding effect, in fact, is happening. We see that, and I affirm that. And we can say just a terrific Q4 results and terrific DR performance. On the macro side, to Marc's marks point, we have $11 billion of booked and billed and unbilled deferred revenue, that gives you a lot of confidence. When you see our big deals coming in like Keith referenced, it gives you the confidence, when you see the business performing across geos, across clouds, that gives you the confidence that our book of business and what we're hearing from our customers is basically caused us to raise our guidance. And that's what we're seeing. Now we read the same newspaper as everybody else. We're not seeing an economic impact. We're seeing customers doing the kind of things that we talked about earlier in the call. So hopefully, that helps.

And I'll just get back to my first comment. It was across all sectors of the business, in product, in geography and in enterprise and SMB. And Keith, could you just address Kash's question specifically in terms of what we're seeing and how we're able to create such large transactions?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Marc. So look, first of all, I would say that this is absolutely been an outstanding set of execution across the board and all market segments, the quarter broader market and the enterprise space, obviously, is very focus and emphasis area fo
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Marc. So look, first of all, I would say that this is absolutely been an outstanding set of execution across the board and all market segments, the quarter broader market and the enterprise space, obviously, is very focus and emphasis area for us over the past few years. If I were to characterize these 2 transactions in particular, I would tell you that they are CEO level sales. We are in the boardroom. And [indiscernible] customers, as Marc had indicated earlier, are looking for our help to bring them into the age of the customer. They're looking[indiscernible] the concept of digital transformation. They view us as the market leader and really the only company that is uniquely positioned to provide them with that transformation, with that level of transformation. And what is happening is a very large deals. It's happening in every deal where these customers are viewing us as their trusted adviser, and that is becoming a norm. And this is a company that has been happening over time. And we continue to see this as we move forward. We're very excited about what's happening here in terms of the market dynamics.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, Marc Benioff, if you could talk to us a little bit about your vision for analytics? I know the products relatively new. I guess I'm wondering out of Dreamforce, if you could give us an update on the types of customer conversations you're
componenttext: I was wondering, Marc Benioff, if you could talk to us a little bit about your vision for analytics? I know the products relatively new. I guess I'm wondering out of Dreamforce, if you could give us an update on the types of customer conversations you're having in regards to analytics. And if you were to look at kind of 3 to 5 years, what are you -- how do you think about -- there's obviously multiple different vendors right now that can do analytics on top of the Salesforce Platform. How do you think of your own offering, kind of replacing those people that are piggybacking on top of CRM deployments today?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Heather, I will -- I think it's a great question. And really, it's a huge focus here at Salesforce. Of course, analytics applications have been an incredible part of the CRM market for a long time. And there are many vendors who offer analytics appl
componenttext: Well, Heather, I will -- I think it's a great question. And really, it's a huge focus here at Salesforce. Of course, analytics applications have been an incredible part of the CRM market for a long time. And there are many vendors who offer analytics applications on our platform. When we first introduce our way of capability which was just a little over a year ago, we didn't introduce applications, we introduced a platform, we introduced the ability to build analytics applications using our way of platform, and we said that this strategy was going to be quite differentiated from others because we were going to be platform first. We were going to build an ecosystem. And then we will later build these applications and then we would later build all of these capabilities from the platform into all of our products and it's all of our ISP capabilities as well. And that's where we are today, I think, that there isn't customer or demonstration or a new sales that's happening where this analytics capability is not a huge part of what we offer to customer. This is analytics as a service. This is scalability that runs on your phone, on your tablet. This runs on your desktop, this runs on your watch. This is a multi-tenant fully scalable system. It has all the characteristics that every other Salesforce products that you know and love that's deeply integrated into our core platform, which is Lightning. And it's amazing. The growth is terrific. We're going to -- I believe we are going to start to see incredible breakout this fiscal year that we're starting now. And we're just finishing our fiscal year kickoff the last 2 days here in San Francisco. And Wave was a huge part of the emphasis of what we're going to do this year. So you're going to see a lot of those products. We're very excited about these capabilities. It's an incredible platform. And I will tell -- as [indiscernible] my hand here that we have been demonstrating internally here a number of core Wave applications, including our new sales Wave capability, which is our sales application built-on Wave, service Wave, service capabilities, marketing Wave, marketing capabilities. And even Mark Hawkins here has built a full set of applications that help him run his entire financial business. And so it's an exciting new product, and we couldn't to be more excited to be in the analytics business.

componenttextpreview: The App Cloud was your fastest-growing cloud and has shown really nice acceleration. Can you just give us a sense of what you're seeing in some of these deals with the App Cloud? And I guess just to follow on with Keith to the prior question. This of year
componenttext: The App Cloud was your fastest-growing cloud and has shown really nice acceleration. Can you just give us a sense of what you're seeing in some of these deals with the App Cloud? And I guess just to follow on with Keith to the prior question. This of year of the macro has been weighing on a lot of customers, some of the comments from other your brother. Can you just give as a signal? It doesn't sound like any [indiscernible] a bit some of the [indiscernible] but just give us a sense of kind of what we're seeing on some of the customer conversations as you look out the next couple of quarters?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think everyone is customers are looking to build applications faster than ever before. And customers want to a build applications once and deploy them on every modern platform, which includes a watch, a phone, a tablet, a PC, and many different ty
componenttext: Sure. I think everyone is customers are looking to build applications faster than ever before. And customers want to a build applications once and deploy them on every modern platform, which includes a watch, a phone, a tablet, a PC, and many different types of tablets and many different types of PCs, and many different types of phones. And we have delivered the most modern, most incredible application development and the point of platform, I believe in the enterprise today, which is Lightning. And you've heard Accenture talked about on our February to launch how it's accelerating their own ability to build applications, not only internally, but for their customers using our Lightning platform because there's nothing else like it. Companies in the software industry has kind of doubled down and bounce back and focused on building apps and kind of getting their apps to be kind of sexier and looking better on all these new devices. And that's a huge mistake because what these software company should be focus on his building platforms that can deliver these apps. And that's what Salesforce has done. It delivered this incredible Lightning platform. It's amazing what it can do to. I mean you even saw on the February 2 launch, we delivered our Lightning platform's running on Microsoft Continuum before Microsoft has been able to deliver their own applications running on Microsoft Continuum because of the kind of flexibility and the capabilities of Lightning. And also, I would point out, that's our strategy as to my comment with other on Wave that is we have this incredible platform with our -- with Wave to build this analytic apps. And I think you know that we have the most -- the #1 platform on Amazon Web Services for building applications they're called Heroku. And between Heroku, between Wave, but Lightning and other capabilities that we have, this will give developers a fast, easy, and very low-cost way to build and deploy enterprise apps. And I would probably give you this great example of this company called who with a lot of momentum out of our Dreamforce conference, with this incredible application that they had built using Lightning, and they ended up in my office in November, and that was awesome. And I was like, how did you build this? They're like, we just build all of this and Lightning? I mean I saw this app was running to my dream this is an incredible app, running on the watch, on the phone, on the tablet, everything and making salespeople more productive and more successful. And customer service professionals more successful and more productive. And I'd say, how did you build that Lightning, Lightning, Lightning. And I'm like, wow. And of course, I'd like so much about the company. And I think that I hope I get to buy more Lightning companies because within 30 days, I've already fully integrated that into my product, launched the new product, Sales Cloud Lightning which includes [indiscernible] capability. And in addition to that, I've got a fully expanded and extended capabilities across my whole product line. So I hope there's more Lightning ISVs that our team that come into our family because I mean, this is like auto integration once they've gone to our Lightning platform and our ability to distribute that through this multithousand person distribution organization of all this momentum is really an awesome thing. So it is all about platform. It's a key differentiator for us. Of course, we've got a great company. That the key differentiator for us. Of course, with ecosystem. That's the key difference hater for us. And it's also about this robust platform that's a key differentiator for us. And that's how we're winning all these deals. I think you kind of figure out our secret sauce.

componenttextpreview: I'll try this again. Just my question earlier was for Keith. Obviously, the European business is accelerating nicely over the last year. You guys put the a lot of investment into that region. I just wondered if you can talk about a momentum in that area,
componenttext: I'll try this again. Just my question earlier was for Keith. Obviously, the European business is accelerating nicely over the last year. You guys put the a lot of investment into that region. I just wondered if you can talk about a momentum in that area, in the ability for that to continue into fiscal '17? And then just a really quick follow-up to your earlier point around transformational deals. There's a lot of discussions around IT budgets fluctuating around on a macro environment. When it comes to CRM, I think we should be thinking that you guys tap into your budgets well beyond just IT now. Is that a fair comment? I think you're alluding to it earlier, but I just want to sort of clarify that as well.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me talk about to so we can hear you loud and clear. So thanks for the question. So first of all, just on the  EMEA, I mean, one of our growth strategy is to be an international expansion. And that is certainly proving out in terms of the numbers. And
componenttext: Let me talk about to so we can hear you loud and clear. So thanks for the question. So first of all, just on the  EMEA, I mean, one of our growth strategy is to be an international expansion. And that is certainly proving out in terms of the numbers. And that takes many forms. There's customer-facing, it's support resources. It's our data centers. It's although sort of things that really have expanded our footprint internationally and certainly in EMEA that has very, very well for us. Let me just give you an example. Our 2 customers. Incredible unsolicited CEO level remarks at the World Economy Forum. We have entered into a relationship that we talked about on this call before with ADD. And at the world economic forum, up in their many session where the CEOs of these companies will be host a transformational meeting that talks a little bit with under CEOs about what they're doing, what they see in the industry. And certainly ADD was doing that. And at the end of the meeting, the CEO of ADD stood up unsolicited and listen, I am completely transformed in the way and sell to service customers and engage with them because I've chosen Salesforce as my trusted partner. And that, of course, is a very significant company in Europe. Schneider-Electric is another -- the CEO of Schneider-Electric was a in the panel with Marc talking about digital transformation. Unsolicited comment on Schneider-Electric is transforming its service model because of the capabilities of Salesforce. So we have some of the most incredible global companies in the world who happen to be headquartered in EMEA who are actually evangelizing our message in the marketplace around transformation and connecting the customers inside the new wave. So when you see market leaders coming out there and as a CEO level and evangelizing our story, that's certainly send a great message to other companies whether they're in that industry or not. So again, those are 2 proof points on EMEA. On the line of business questions in terms of budgets, look, IT organizations always have budgets. They typically run to between 1% to 2% of the company revenues. But what we've been able to tap into beyond those budgets are the line of business executives budgets. And also as we've discussed on this call, the CEO agenda. It's an amazing phenomenon when you see the CEO who has a growth priority realigning the budgets in a corporation to take on these growth initiatives. And that's what we're seeing. So it goes well beyond IT. Certainly, IT budgets are a particular component. But when the priority of the company is all about growth, you find the money to make that happen. You find the money to make those investments, and that's what we're seeing in the marketplace.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question for Mark Hawkins. Your guidance for the year in terms of operating margin towards the lower end of your range, I think 100 to 300 basis points of margin expansion with your revenue growth at the lower end of that as well. But can you talk about s
componenttext: Question for Mark Hawkins. Your guidance for the year in terms of operating margin towards the lower end of your range, I think 100 to 300 basis points of margin expansion with your revenue growth at the lower end of that as well. But can you talk about sort of how you're thinking about that, that prior framework for margins and is there or anything going on this year that we should think about impacting sort of how you're gearing to that grid?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Walter, first, thanks for the question and I'm happy to address that question. We're really pleased coming off with a great year and a great finish where we beat our operating margin guidance. We delivered 177 basis points this last year. And on top
componenttext: Sure. Walter, first, thanks for the question and I'm happy to address that question. We're really pleased coming off with a great year and a great finish where we beat our operating margin guidance. We delivered 177 basis points this last year. And on top of that, consistent with our revenue margin framework, I'll go ahead and do that 125 to 150 basis points for FY '17. We feel that's really appropriate in light of our framework, it's consistent with it. We think it's appropriate and good guide. And it also allows us to propel this growth to really help our customers, saw the need they have and invest in the future to perpetuate this performance over the long term. So that's what I would say, Walter.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question for Marc Benioff. So we are hearing more discussion of transformational types of projects where Salesforce is displacing many legacy systems and is being used wall to wall. And so there's always a view that the company has evolved from being a si
componenttext: Question for Marc Benioff. So we are hearing more discussion of transformational types of projects where Salesforce is displacing many legacy systems and is being used wall to wall. And so there's always a view that the company has evolved from being a single engine to a 3 or 4 engine aircraft. So I'm curious, when you look at the larger transactions, how commonly is a large deal just for a single cloud? Because I think being in the prior cycle, in the past, some of them were versus how commonly is it viewed as really a single Customer Success Platform. And just from the beginning, it's going to be spanning sales service marketing platform and everything else?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's a great question and I'll tell you I believe that that's a huge driver for us going forward, because still only, I think the number is 72% of customers still use us for only 1 cloud. So that is 72% of customers still only use either t
componenttext: Well, I think that's a great question and I'll tell you I believe that that's a huge driver for us going forward, because still only, I think the number is 72% of customers still use us for only 1 cloud. So that is 72% of customers still only use either the Sales Cloud or the Service Cloud or the Marketing Cloud or the platform or analytics or whatever. And the opportunity is to do exactly what you said, which is to deliver the Customer Success Platform. And we do want to go wall to wall these companies. They do see the opportunities more and more. With some premium customers, we have had that opportunity. And I believe that, that is a huge opportunity for this company as it continues to grow and expand that we have a rich portfolio of product to offer these customers even though the vast majority of customers has only chosen one of those products so far.

componenttextpreview: A question for Mark Hawkins. Mark, I would you mind going back to the Q1 DR guide which I think it implies billings growth in a mid-teens level and your seasonality question? You definitely told us before that deal activity, especially renewals to 4Q, whi
componenttext: A question for Mark Hawkins. Mark, I would you mind going back to the Q1 DR guide which I think it implies billings growth in a mid-teens level and your seasonality question? You definitely told us before that deal activity, especially renewals to 4Q, which obviously makes the sequential DR and billings growth comparison tough in 1Q. I'm just curious, is this expected to be a greater than normal impact in this Q1? And are there any other issues that worth lagging that are impacting Q1 DR?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, Karl. Thank you for the question. I think you're getting it right on which as you describe it exactly right. The compounding effect that we described at Dreamforce a reality. More and more of our DR are showing up in Q4. It impacts all the seq
componenttext: Absolutely, Karl. Thank you for the question. I think you're getting it right on which as you describe it exactly right. The compounding effect that we described at Dreamforce a reality. More and more of our DR are showing up in Q4. It impacts all the sequential growth rates more and more as we show them amplified set of data that we referenced. But it kind of build on to your point. There is one of the things that you are trying to make sure that everyone sees and to call out, so I appreciate your question. That's regarding leap year, and it's a seems like a simple enough point. But when you take a look at our revenue and when you divide it by day when there's 1 extra day, that has the effect of having $20 million of extra revenue recognition in Q1 even know it all washes out in the year, right? But when you have 1 extra day of revenue, it means you have 1 less they of deferred revenue effectively. And so that's the other thing you take a look at. So if you take a look t the compounding effect, and you adjust for the leap year, which washes all out in the year but not in the quarter, I think you'll see just the kind of an appropriate pattern there for a guide, okay?

componenttext: Let me direct this question to Marc Benioff and to Keith as well. You both talked about the systems integrated as partners and customers during the quarter. I love to hear the role that those SIs are playing in the bigger enterprise deal. And more interested here today sent that you do have some systems integrators partners that are consuming a lot of salesforce.com that they're doing so it internally and how that's shaping their practice?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there hasn't been a conversation in this quarter that has revolved around the incredible success that we've had with Accenture. We're not only fast-growing business unit. But also we've now deployed already 25,000 users of Salesforce inside
componenttext: Well, I think there hasn't been a conversation in this quarter that has revolved around the incredible success that we've had with Accenture. We're not only fast-growing business unit. But also we've now deployed already 25,000 users of Salesforce inside Accenture. You've heard of their CIO and their CEO come to our launch on February 2 and get personal testimonial to the success that they've had that deer only regret is they did it go faster with Salesforce that they're transforming their customer relationships that are on a hurdle rates. And this is having a broad ripple effect through the SI community where I think that honestly, they're all asking themselves why are they not all using the Salesforce, building that app on Salesforce and selling Salesforce and having the same great success that Accenture has had. Some of these SIs are kind of prima donnas who have held on to the past too long and it's affected their growth rates and ability to work with customers and then in some cases dislodge them from strategic customers situations because they were not able to move fast enough to understand these customers' needs and got displaced by Accenture. And the we're seeing that in mass. And it's a -- for sure, is a shot across the bow of the SI community that they better go faster when there is going to be a broad shakeup in regards to the transformations that are happening underway in regards to these next-generation implementations, specifically those regarding Salesforce and our product line. Keith?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, great question. So first and foremost, I think you all recognize that these SIs, many of them, certainly the upper SIs, very strategic influencers in the boardroom and at a CEO level and thinking transformation to these business executives. Part of o
componenttext: Yes, great question. So first and foremost, I think you all recognize that these SIs, many of them, certainly the upper SIs, very strategic influencers in the boardroom and at a CEO level and thinking transformation to these business executives. Part of our strategy is has been to really strengthen these relationships over time because we know that they bring expertise and asset. They can also drive most importantly the customer success. The alteration I would give you is that the most successful SIs are the ones who are very focused on Salesforce and the ones to actually run their business on Salesforce. Markets given you an example. And we are establishing, what I would call a 360-degree relationship with these SIs. So we go to market with these SIs. They've got a business on Salesforce and in the case of Accentue, they're actually building product. They become a ISV. And they are sort of strategic relationships that we're trying to build here, and we've been very, very successful. And the ones who get it are growing. I had a conversation last week with a CEO of a pretty major consulting organization who was lamenting about their lack of growth, generally speaking. And my comments to this person was quite candidly, you're not focused enough on Salesforce because if you're focused on Salesforce, your business will be growing. And I got this look at the acknowledgment and it's absolutely true. The success stories in these consulting practices, they develop their Salesforce practice. So they've been part of the growth strategy. They're starting to virtually all the large ones are running their business on Salesforce. They made their commitments and they're a big part of our future and our ecosystem strategy.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your final question comes from the line of Alex Zukin with Stephens.
componenttext: And your final question comes from the line of Alex Zukin with Stephens.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marc, there's been some investor and customer dialogue lately touching on that theme that Salesforce is becoming a little bit more like Oracle. As you continued your drive to be the largest software company of the world, how does Salesforce aspire to be d
componenttext: Marc, there's been some investor and customer dialogue lately touching on that theme that Salesforce is becoming a little bit more like Oracle. As you continued your drive to be the largest software company of the world, how does Salesforce aspire to be different from then and others going forward while balancing your various constituencies.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's a great question and something that we think about every day at Salesforce and something that we have talked about every day at Salesforce, which is what kind of company is this and what is our culture, who are you we and what it is t
componenttext: Well, I think that's a great question and something that we think about every day at Salesforce and something that we have talked about every day at Salesforce, which is what kind of company is this and what is our culture, who are you we and what it is that we do. And we've talked a lot about that on the call already that we have erratically different technology model than the technology model that have been in place at Oracle or SAP or even Microsoft. We have, which is our multi-tenancy system, both on our metadata model. We have a radically different customer model, which is our model built on customer success. And we have a radically different from profit model that we have talked about which is our focus on 1% of our equity, our profit and our employees time go into our Salesforce.org. So we of course, done [ph] about 1.3 million hours of community service I believe. It was even more community service this year than Microsoft, which is a company 10x our size. So we're just very committed to volunteer. We run over 25,000 nonprofit and NGOs for free, which has been a gift of over $250 million in services to the nonprofit community. And we've given a little over $100 million in grants as well. I think also, we're out there fighting for equality where we can. You saw that with our focus on equal pay for women. We are just that the White House speaking about that. Adjustments that we've made on the financial so that we can pay women the same that we pay men here at Salesforce. You saw a slight than Indiana against discrimination of our employees, and we're looking squarely at what's going on in Georgia with House Bill 757, which means that we may have to reduce our investments in the state of Georgia based on what we're seeing with the state government there as well. And I hope that they see like the way that the state of Indiana did. And in addition, I think that you see Salesforce trying to create a culture in an environment where we reflect -- we think the future of the world is, a world where there needs to be more equality, world where there is need to be more focus on sustainability and where there needs to be a world focused on companies that are becoming platform for change. And that's a business-to-business improving the state of the world. Those are the things that are really important to us. I think also probably you noticed that we opened up this call saying thank you. It's really important to us that we have a sense of gratitude when we address our employees and our customers and our partners. That's a huge part of our culture. And at the end of the day, it's deeply a part of customers' success as well that is because of our business model, we're only successful if our customers are successful. So these are the things that I think that are actually somewhat different than when we were at Oracle, the narrative there and the actions, the behavior was rewarded differently to things that were encouraged to do in compensated for. And what we told our employees do and what we direct them to do, it's different than what we do in Salesforce, and I hope that we can be an example, a benevolent company that does well and does good.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks so much, Ashley. Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us for our fiscal fourth quarter and full year 2016 results conference call. Our fourth quarter results press release, SEC filings and a replay of today's call can be found on our IR
componenttext:
Thanks so much, Ashley. Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us for our fiscal fourth quarter and full year 2016 results conference call. Our fourth quarter results press release, SEC filings and a replay of today's call can be found on our IR website at www.salesforce.com/investor.
With me on the call today is Marc Benioff, Chairman and CEO; Keith Block, Vice Chairman, President and COO; and Mark Hawkins, CFO.
As a reminder, our commentary today will primarily be in non-GAAP terms. Reconciliations between our GAAP and non-GAAP results and guidance can be found in our earnings press release.
Some of our comments today may also contain forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks, uncertainties and assumptions. Should any of these materialize or should any of our assumptions prove to be incorrect, actual company results could differ materially from these forward-looking statements. A description of our risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that could affect our financial results are included in our SEC filings, including our most recent report on Forms 10-K and 10-Q.
With that, let me turn the call over to Marc.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, John. And we -- this is our biggest call ever. We've got over 500 people around the world who are dialed in into the call. So we know there's a lot of interest in the quarter. And we've made a decision we're going to put aside the vast major
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, John. And we -- this is our biggest call ever. We've got over 500 people around the world who are dialed in into the call. So we know there's a lot of interest in the quarter. And we've made a decision we're going to put aside the vast majority of our script so that we can get into Q&A as fast as possible with you. 
Look, my #1 thing I want to tell you is this is the absolute best quarter we have ever had. It's been just an incredible quarter, way beyond our expectations. It caps an incredible fiscal year for us. I'm sure that you saw that revenues for the quarter rose to $1.8 billion, and that's up 27%, which is really just amazing. Revenue for the full fiscal year was also up 27%, $6.7 billion. 
So you look at those things, and you go, wow, I mean, that's a very fast growth rate for a company of our size and scale. We're top 10 enterprise software company. You all know the growth rates of Microsoft, Oracle, SAP are shrinking; negative growth rates in many cases. And here, we are at a 27% growth rate in this enterprise applications market. And as you get -- as Keith gets into it, you're going to hear that we believe that we're selling more enterprise apps than Oracle or SAP. 
Deferred revenue grew to nearly $4.3 billion, which was up 31%. Quarterly operating cash flow was nearly $460 million, up 38%. That number, of course, exceeded everyone's expectation and took us by surprise as well. And we are really proud of that number, $460 million quarterly operating cash flow in the quarter. Full year operating cash flow was $1.6 billion, up 37%; and the dollar value of booked business on and off the balance sheet, $11 billion. That is obviously a huge a number for us, something that we've never had before, and it's really a huge reflection of the amount of business that has been achieved in the fiscal year and, specifically, in the quarter as well. 
We've got great momentum going into our first quarter. We're guiding to an incredible number here and, $1.895 billion, at the high end of our range. And for the full year, we're increasing our revenue guidance to $8.12 billion. So we are really excited and aggressive in our guidance. And it's -- yes, it was an amazing quarter. It was an amazing year. We are confident that it's going to be an amazing first quarter. And no other enterprise software company of our size and scale is delivering at this level or as excited as we are. And no one else is as well positioned for the sake of the customer that we are all moving into in this Fourth Industrial Revolution. 
Before I hand the call now over to Keith, I just want to thank all of our customers, and I want to thank all of our partners, and I also want to congratulate all 20,000 of our employees on an amazing year. We are deeply, deeply, deeply grateful for everything that you do for us everyday. And we don't forget that for one moment, every single day with us, that Salesforce start with gratitude. And we know that this is a special time, and we're grateful for all the hard work that everyone has put in. 
Also, I know you were going to want to catch us on our world tour that's coming up, and big events are starting next month. You'll see us at CeBIT in Germany and in Chicago, Boston, Melbourne, Amsterdam. We'll be in Washington, D.C. as well. So come to one of our events. 
And we've got a great new COO here at Salesforce as well. So Keith, congratulations on your promotion. Well done.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Marc.
componenttext: Thank you very much, Marc.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And why don't you tell us about the quarter?
componenttext: And why don't you tell us about the quarter?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. Listen, this was an amazing quarter. Our team -- really, the whole company delivered the best quarter in 19 years here at Salesforce. It was a breakthrough quarter. It certainly was a breakthrough year for us, and it translated into some ama
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. Listen, this was an amazing quarter. Our team -- really, the whole company delivered the best quarter in 19 years here at Salesforce. It was a breakthrough quarter. It certainly was a breakthrough year for us, and it translated into some amazing results in every region, every industry and, really, across companies of all sizes. We signed 2 of the largest deals that I've seen in my career. I mean, absolutely fantastic. I mean, first, we signed an exciting, new 9-figure transaction to one of the world's most respected companies. And second, we signed the largest renewal in the history of the company. And listen, they didn't just renew, they also significantly expanded their 9-figure relationship with us in Q4. And we are now their company-wide platform for innovation. I mean, it's really amazing what the team has done and how these customers have embraced us. 
We also drove an all-time high in the number of large transaction this year, which is incredible, more than 600 7-figure-plus transactions in the quarter. And I'll tell you, Marc said it, I'll say it again, no one in enterprise software, no one in enterprise software is developing more strategic relationships right now than Salesforce. 
And you know what, there's no better example of this than Unilever, which is one of the world's greatest consumer packaged goods companies. It's a great digital transformation story and a significant, significant expansion for us here in Q4. We've been delivering great levels of success with our consumer and marketing teams. We're now working across all business functions. And Unilever plans to bring 95,000 of their employees onto the Salesforce Platform, so that means that they are empowering their digital employee strategy to new levels of engagement. 
Now Charles Schwab, another great brand, is an exciting new relationship in the quarter. They'll be using Salesforce for their entire CRM platform. This is a great example of how Ignite and industry team had played a pivotal role winning an important customer. As you all know, Ignite is part of our go-to-market motion. 
Also, I mean, we had mentioned in Q1, if you remember, we had told you about our largest Marketing Cloud win ever. Then, we signed an even bigger one in Q3. And in Q4, we did it again. We topped ourselves, and we entered into our largest Marketing Cloud relationship ever with a large social network. In fact, Marketing Cloud continues its success and increase the number of large Marketing Cloud transactions by more than 60% in the past year. 
Also, one of the largest resellers in the world expanded with us in the quarter and selected Salesforce as their company-wide collaboration platform. And you know what, there are many, many, many more stories. There -- these are some of the world's greatest brands, some of the greatest stories, and we continue to deepen our strategic relationships with all of them. I mean, this is great momentum. It's incredible momentum and growth across all of our key industries, in all of our key markets. 
And I will say again, as Marc did, I'm very, very proud of the entire company for all of these accomplishments. All our outstanding results are just proof positive that our strategy is absolutely more than taking hold. I'd also like to thank our customers and our partners because they are helping us set the standard for this industry. 
So with that, I'll hand it over to Mark Hawkins.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Keith. We had an incredible financial quarter, so let me start off with some highlights. In addition to the operating cash flow results Marc mentioned, we continue to drive increased operating leverage. For the full year, we increased our non-GA
componenttext:
Thanks, Keith. We had an incredible financial quarter, so let me start off with some highlights. 
In addition to the operating cash flow results Marc mentioned, we continue to drive increased operating leverage. For the full year, we increased our non-GAAP operating margin by 177 basis points. This is a great result as we continue to grow our top line. Our year-over-year growth was balanced across all of our clouds and all of our regions: Sales Cloud accelerated in the quarter with 12% growth; Service Cloud grew 35%; Marketing Cloud grew 31%; and App Cloud and others grew 43%. 
In the regions, EMEA grew 32%, and APAC continues to accelerate at 26% growth, both in constant currency. 
We also got off to a great start in Q4, and that early quarter strength translated into strong billings and collections in the quarter and helped drive our cash flow in Q4. It also helped us drive our top line performance in Q4. And when you exclude the FX effect of $32 million, revenue was up 27% in constant currency. 
Supporting this great top line growth was our decline in attrition rate, which remains below 9%. Our deferred revenue in the quarter reached an all-time high of $4.3 billion. This was up 31% in constant currency when excluding an FX effect of $48 million. We also continue to drive an increase in annual billings in the quarter, with 88% of all our subscription and support-related invoices issued with annual terms. This benefited year-over-year deferred revenue growth in the quarter by approximately 3 percentage points. 
Moving on to guidance. Coming off a strong Q4 and with our proven business model, we are raising our FY '17 revenue guidance to $8.12 billion, at the high end of the range. And we're also initiating FY '17 non-GAAP EPS guidance of $0.99 to $1.01. In context, we expect to deliver 125  to 150 basis points of non-GAAP operating margin improvement in FY '17. And this is just coming off a year where we exceeded the high end of our FY '16 operating margin guidance. As a result of this, we continue margin expansion. We expect to drive another full year of strong operating cash flow, with year-over-year growth of 23% to 24%. For Q1, we're expecting revenue of $1.885 billion to $1.895 billion, non-GAAP EPS of $0.23 to $0.24 and year-over-year deferred revenue growth of 24% to 25%. 
A quick note on our Q1 guide. As all of you know, FY '17 is a leap year. And given we recognize our revenue on a daily basis, there's an extra day of subscription revenue in the first quarter. This will benefit our first quarter revenue by approximately $20 million that will drive a slightly higher non-GAAP EPS and will reduce our deferred revenue by the corresponding amount. This is simply a timing item that has no impact on the full FY '17 fiscal year results, but this will have an impact on your quarterly and full year compares in FY '18. 
To close, we had an outstanding quarter and year, and we are well on -- well positioned for yet another great year in FY '17. And at this time, I'd like to add my thanks to the entire Salesforce team for these great results. 
With that, I'd like to open up the call for questions.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Keith Weiss with Morgan Stanley.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the question I want to ask was the why to Mr. Benioff. It's not -- like you're saying, not many companies of this scale actually see accelerating growth. Anything you could point us to in terms why you guys are seeing this now? What's really just
componenttext: I guess the question I want to ask was the why to Mr. Benioff. It's not -- like you're saying, not many companies of this scale actually see accelerating growth. Anything you could point us to in terms why you guys are seeing this now? What's really just clicking on in the business to let you guys accelerate? Maybe if I could squeeze in one for Mr. Hawkins. Just in terms of as we're thinking about FY '17, the business is beginning to be [indiscernible] seasonal, so in terms of Q1, the growth will be lower and more growth in the back half of the year. Given the current sort of economic environment, how do you garner confidence in the ability to stay at this 20% plus growth for the full year of FY '17?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our growth strategy is really built on having a full portfolio of products -- I think you know about that -- in sales, in service, in marketing, in community, in analytics, in apps, in the IoT; and as well as a full portfolio of geographies as well,
componenttext: Well, our growth strategy is really built on having a full portfolio of products -- I think you know about that -- in sales, in service, in marketing, in community, in analytics, in apps, in the IoT; and as well as a full portfolio of geographies as well, doing business around the world like in the United States, in Japan, in Europe, Australia and Canada; and in addition to doing business with enterprises and as well as small and medium businesses. And when that full portfolio accelerates, that is they all come in, in the quarter, which we really never expect every product and every geography and both enterprise and SMB to come in, then you get this kind of accelerated revenue growth, which is what you see is this 27% number on both the year and the quarter. And it's -- as I said, in my opening remarks, this is the best quarter we've ever seen. We would never expect to see every product group and every geography and every sector of our business exceed our expectations. So that's what we saw in the fourth quarter, and that creates this phenomenal momentum that we have now. And look at that number on and off the balance sheet, $11 billion; there's no greater predictor of our future success than this deferred revenue that we now have in place.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And let me pick up the second half of that question that you directed. Just building on Marc's comments, I think you'd asked a little bit about the seasonality in FY '17, starting with Q1. Back at our Analyst Day Keith is referring to, we looked at
componenttext: Great. And let me pick up the second half of that question that you directed. Just building on Marc's comments, I think you'd asked a little bit about the seasonality in FY '17, starting with Q1. Back at our Analyst Day Keith is referring to, we looked at this compounding effect; and more and more of our renewals and business happening and then showing up in Q4, showing up in the NPAT and DR; and then having a quarter-on-quarter effect throughout the year, that compounding effect, in fact, is happening. We see that, and I affirm that. And we can say it's just a terrific Q4 result and a terrific DR performance. On the macro side, to Marc's point, when you have $11 billion of booked and billed and unbilled deferred revenue, that gives you a lot of confidence. When you see our big deals coming in, like Keith referenced, that gives you the confidence, when you see the business performing across geos, across clouds, that gives you the confidence that our book of business and what we're hearing from the customer, it basically caused us to raise our guidance. And that's what we're seeing. Now we read the same newspapers as everybody else. We're not seeing a economic impact. We're seeing customers doing the kind of things that we've talked about earlier in the call. So hopefully, that helps.

componenttextpreview: So Kash, you made a very good point, which is these are very unusual transactions, and we never like to overemphasize these transactions because they tend to be few and far between because they are just exceptional in size, quality and depth. But we had a
componenttext: So Kash, you made a very good point, which is these are very unusual transactions, and we never like to overemphasize these transactions because they tend to be few and far between because they are just exceptional in size, quality and depth. But we had a -- an incredible renewal with one of the world's largest insurance companies, and we had an incredible new transaction with one of the world's largest professional services companies. And it really, I think, is a testament to some of the processes that Keith has put into place in regards to the enterprise, and then I'll let him speak to that. And I want to also make the comment that it's not just those 2 large transactions, but you heard what Keith had to say about the broad range of large transactions that were 7- and 8-digit deals as well. And I'll just get back to my first comment. It was across all sectors of the business, in product, in geography and in enterprise and SMB. And Keith, will you just address Kash's questions specifically in terms of what we're seeing and how we're able to create such large transactions?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Marc. So look, Kash, first of all, I would say that this has absolutely been a -- an outstanding set of execution across the board in all market segments. The broader market and the enterprise space, this obviously has been a focus and emphas
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Marc. So look, Kash, first of all, I would say that this has absolutely been a -- an outstanding set of execution across the board in all market segments. The broader market and the enterprise space, this obviously has been a focus and emphasis area for us over the past few years. If I were to characterize these 2 transactions in particular, I would tell you that they are CEO-level sales. We are in the boardroom and find ourselves in a position where our customers, as Marc had indicated earlier, are looking for our help to bring them into the age of the customer. They are looking to embrace the concept and notion of digital transformation. They view us as the market leader and, really, the only company that is uniquely positioned to provide them with that transformation -- with that level of transformation. And this -- and what is happening in these very large deals, it's happening in every deal, where these customers are viewing us as a trusted adviser, and that is becoming the norm. And this is a company that has been happening for some period of time, and we continue to see this as we move forward. We're very excited about what's happening here in terms of the market dynamics.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, Marc Benioff, if you could talk to us a little bit about your vision for analytics? I know the product's relatively new. I guess I'm just wondering out of Dreamforce, if you could give us an update on the types of customer conversations y
componenttext: I was wondering, Marc Benioff, if you could talk to us a little bit about your vision for analytics? I know the product's relatively new. I guess I'm just wondering out of Dreamforce, if you could give us an update on the types of customer conversations you're having in regards to analytics. And if you were to look out kind of 3 to 5 years, what do you -- how do you think about -- there's obviously multiple different vendors right now that can do analytics on top of the Salesforce Platform. How do you think of your own offering kind of replacing those people that are piggybacking on top of CRM deployments today?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Heather, I -- well, I think it's a great question, and really, it's a huge focus here at Salesforce. Of course, analytics applications have been an incredible part of the CRM market for a long time. And there aren't many vendors who offer analytics
componenttext: Well, Heather, I -- well, I think it's a great question, and really, it's a huge focus here at Salesforce. Of course, analytics applications have been an incredible part of the CRM market for a long time. And there aren't many vendors who offer analytics applications on our platform. When we first introduced our way of capability, which was just a little over a year ago, we didn't introduce applications, we introduced a platform, we introduced the ability to build analytics applications using our way of platform. And we said that this strategy was going to be quite differentiated from others because we were going to be platform first, we are going to build an ecosystem, and then we would later build these applications, and then we would later build all of these capabilities from the platform into all of our products and into all of our ISP capabilities as well. And that's where we are today. I think that there isn't a customer or a demonstration or a new sale that's happening where this analytics capability is not a huge part of what we offer to customer. This is analytics as a service. This is scalability. This runs on your phone, on your tablet; this runs on your desktop; this runs on your watch. This is a multitenant, fully scalable system. It has all the characteristics of every other Salesforce products that you know and love, that's deeply integrated into our core platform, which is Lightning, and way is this amazing. The growth is terrific. We're going to, I believe, start to see an incredible breakout this fiscal year that we're starting now. And we're just finishing our fiscal year kickoff the last 2 days here in San Francisco. And Wave was a huge part of the emphasis of what we're going to do this year. So you're going to see a lot of that products. We're very excited about these capabilities. It's an incredible platform. And I will tell -- [indiscernible] my hand here, that we have been demonstrating internally here a number of core Wave applications, including our new Sales Wave capability, which is our sales applications built on Wave; Service Wave, service capabilities; marketing Wave, marketing capabilities. And even Mark Hawkins here has built a full set of applications that help him run his entire financial business. And so it's a -- it's an exciting new product, and we're -- we couldn't be more excited to be in the analytics business.

componenttext: Yes, absolutely. I mean, the wheels just turned. And certainly, the -- as we talked about earlier, the CEOs are all about transformation. And they're very interested in us playing the role of technology [ph] adviser. They've been interested in our thought leadership, as you know. And listen, in the last 3 weeks, I've had more conversations with CEOs around transformation than in my entire career over 30-plus years.

And those happened at the World Economic Forum; those happened in their offices; those happened in our offices; those happened at trade shows. But I'll tell you that Keith and I just can't probably rattle off dozens of CEOs, that we are having to constantly interact with and collaborate with in creating these transactions. And I think it's really unusual. And I think that's why we are really selling more enterprise software than Oracle or SAP in the applications area, wouldn't you say, Keith, at this point?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016

componenttext: There is no question that we are outpacing the competition in terms of enterprise application sales. I mean, there is no question, we continue to take share, and that's full market share and mind share. And you and I were having a conversation just the other day about one of the world's largest financial services institution and kind of in the old world, what level we would be able to call on. And in this new world, because we were with them at the World Economic Forum, we're talking to the CIO and -- the CEO. And their CIO and Head of Operations, that person would never have met with us before. And all of a sudden, they are with us all the time. In fact, we have a quote from our kickoff -- we just finished our kickoff -- from the CEO of this particular institution saying that they view Salesforce as one of the most critical strategic partners.

componenttext: And Keith, wouldn't you say that that's really about kind of our company's DNA that kind of transform our world to becoming a trusted advisers, especially in regards to the customer relationships with these companies, isn't that what's going on?

componenttext: Absolutely, and we're bringing a point of view around the industry. And what of the things, as you know, that we focused on is these specific industry messages and these points of view, and that resonates. When you're talking to the CEO, of course, I'm sitting next to one right now, Mr. Marc Benioff, he wants to know the point of view in a particular industry. And those messages are absolutely resonating. And they want to make quick decisions, they want to solve business problems, and  they want to transform, and this is all about transformation.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keith, there seems like there's another level of it, which a lot of them really grow us on our own business because they are moving to subscription-based services themselves. They want to be a cloud company. They want to have Internet of Things capabiliti
componenttext: Keith, there seems like there's another level of it, which a lot of them really grow us on our own business because they are moving to subscription-based services themselves. They want to be a cloud company. They want to have Internet of Things capabilities. They want to be more connected with their customers. They want to understand how we're achieving this growth because many of these companies want us to be [ph] in the same growth levels. How does this impact the conversations?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's interesting that you brought it up. There are 2 types of conversations that we typically find ourselves involved with. And again, this is at a CEO level and in the boardroom. Number one is you can always ask these companies, "Why aren't you thi
componenttext: Well, it's interesting that you brought it up. There are 2 types of conversations that we typically find ourselves involved with. And again, this is at a CEO level and in the boardroom. Number one is you can always ask these companies, "Why aren't you thinking about yourself as a cloud company? Why aren't you thinking about changing your business model?" And you should see the expression on their faces because they're embracing that notion of transformation. So yes, that is certainly one...
