Why don't you give us some color there? And as you think about the rest of fiscal '17, just how do you think about the outlook for the Marketing Cloud in particular? And then just one quick follow-up to that.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we just came up with connections. We all have this incredible event last week in Atlanta where we had a record number of customer show up for this event and a lot of great CMOs, a lot of great C level executives, they love our messaging, they love o
componenttext: Well, we just came up with connections. We all have this incredible event last week in Atlanta where we had a record number of customer show up for this event and a lot of great CMOs, a lot of great C level executives, they love our messaging, they love our vision. And we've done a very, very nice job of integrating, not only integrating I would say that acquisition that we made almost 3 years ago in June of exact [indiscernible] the we continue to strengthen the product. So it is a natural adjacency the customer engagement along with Sales Cloud and Service Cloud. We continue to invest in the product. We continue to invest in the marketing asset as well as our field assets, and we are driving the results and the message continues to resonate.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I would add into that one, too. Keith, I think you guys have landed an amazing big deals in the Marketing Cloud. That's been really productive in that way as well. So it's really nice to see those attributes. Marketing Cloud I think coming along rea
componenttext: John, I would add into that one, too. Keith, I think you guys have landed an amazing big deals in the Marketing Cloud. That's been really productive in that way as well. So it's really nice to see those attributes. Marketing Cloud I think coming along really nicely.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just a follow-up for Marc B. Sales Cloud is obviously been a phenomenal success and is a big dollar number and continues to grow rapidly. It seems like the customer service market as a whole is pretty hot right now. We've heard some new pl
componenttext: Great. And then just a follow-up for Marc B. Sales Cloud is obviously been a phenomenal success and is a big dollar number and continues to grow rapidly. It seems like the customer service market as a whole is pretty hot right now. We've heard some new players try to talk about coming into this space even just this week. When you think about your positioning and sort of what you bring to market here versus some of the existing [indiscernible] also these new ones trying to get into the market, how do you think about your positioning? What advantages do you have? And how do you think about especially the new entrants?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, service is a huge focus of Salesforce, and we -- I was immediately kind of default to again my comment on innovation and was evidence of the innovation, Gartner's lead analyst just published their magic quadrant on customer engagement. If you haven'
componenttext: Well, service is a huge focus of Salesforce, and we -- I was immediately kind of default to again my comment on innovation and was evidence of the innovation, Gartner's lead analyst just published their magic quadrant on customer engagement. If you haven't seen it, we should get it and contact Gartner. And then you'll see that when you get it that Salesforce as we further up into the right of any product that I've ever seen in the history of Gartner's Magic Quadrants. So you have to take a look at that. And we're not done because where we platform in service completely o n the Lightning, which will be done by Dreamforce, we will continue to add an extent service. It remains one of our most exciting fastest-growing product. It's going to -- it is casing Sales Cloud to be our largest cloud. It I mean, it is an exciting market. Now service is a huge and exciting market. There will be many players in service just as there are many players in sales. There's just this many players in platforms. We are in mega markets, and we -- I like that there's innovation in service and competition in service. It makes the markets bigger, but it doesn't change our position as being the #1 most important provider of service solutions in the world with the largest market share. That is where we want to be in continue and where we will continue to be.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just add to that, just in case you haven't seen the report yet. So we gained 330 basis points, and the report just came out. I mean, it's pretty -- it's a pretty major share shift to add on to our already #1 position.
componenttext: And just add to that, just in case you haven't seen the report yet. So we gained 330 basis points, and the report just came out. I mean, it's pretty -- it's a pretty major share shift to add on to our already #1 position.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Mark Murphy with JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Mark Murphy with JPMorgan.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question for Marc Benioff. In recent months, we have seen a lot of evidence of the major consulting firms such as Accenture and Deloitte and PWC moving pretty aggressively to build out their Salesforce practices. They've been doing it both organically and
componenttext: Question for Marc Benioff. In recent months, we have seen a lot of evidence of the major consulting firms such as Accenture and Deloitte and PWC moving pretty aggressively to build out their Salesforce practices. They've been doing it both organically and through acquisitions. And they seem to be centering their entire digital transformation strategy around Salesforce. And we've seen them converging their services with apps from multiple of your app exchange partners, and they're kind of wrapping that around Salesforce and it seems to be resulting in part in this growth trajectory that you've got. So I am curious, does the past even beyond $10 billion and maybe to $15 billion or $20 billion in revenue, seem any clear to you as you have these consulting firms coalescing around Salesforce for their digital transformation strategies?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, this is a great question, and I'm going to go to Keith pretty quickly on this. But you saw it in my February 2 presentation where we highlighted Accenture and we've also now toured around the world. You've seen the videos on YouTube between Sa
componenttext: Okay. Well, this is a great question, and I'm going to go to Keith pretty quickly on this. But you saw it in my February 2 presentation where we highlighted Accenture and we've also now toured around the world. You've seen the videos on YouTube between Salesforce and Accenture, if you haven't. It's a great opportunity. Go and check that out as well as the demos. You've heard from their CIO, from the CEO, from their President. Salesforce is the fastest and most strategic growing practice and it is their transformation practice, it is their key cloud practice. You also see that some of the every major SIs as well. I'm especially proud of our work with Deloitte. I'm especially proud of our work with Cap Gemini. And you know from the fourth quarter, PWC was just an awesome, awesome relationship that is emerging, and we are delighted with that as well. All of these players have our full attention. Now for all of them, they are kind of competing to grow to be the fastest grower with an Salesforce's ecosystem, because all of our customers want service capabilities because Salesforce itself provides actually only strategic services. We don't really provide these kind of core implementation services. So these large players have acquired many of the key parts of our ecosystem, and you just saw that with IBM. They just bought [indiscernible] they just [indiscernible] there as a company but they all made strategic bets on and they are trying to acquire our ecosystem as fast as possible. We're continuing to invest in these companies and in this ecosystem companies. We want to start more companies that provide service capabilities, regionally in the United States, in Europe, in Japan, in Australia coming other places in the world. And these companies grow up and they get acquired by these large companies, that's a great model for us. Of course, our venture firm has made a incredible return on that strategy over the last 10 years. Now on top of that, I will tell you that I don't think that there is a strategic systems integrator who isn't making massive investments in Salesforce right now. And a lot of that has been led by Keith. I'm going to turn it over to him. He's really given us a partner focus [indiscernible] happy for him. Keith, can you kind of tell us how you doubled down on that and now you provided such great leadership are in the systems integrators?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, this has been one of our growth strategies to really drive this partner ecosystem in many fronts. And Marc mentioned a lot of the large and significant players. I mean, these are firms that have deep relationships in the boardroom, companies of
componenttext: So again, this has been one of our growth strategies to really drive this partner ecosystem in many fronts. And Marc mentioned a lot of the large and significant players. I mean, these are firms that have deep relationships in the boardroom, companies of all shapes and sizes all over the world. I mean, Deloitte has rebranded to Deloitte Digital. And really when you look at the centerpiece of everything that Deloitte brings to the table in terms of digital transformation, it starts with Salesforce. They've done a terrific job there. I just -- last week, I addressed the Global Partners Forum at Accenture in Munich and talked about digital transformation in how Accenture and Salesforce are doing so well together. Just to give you an example of Accenture. We just don't ever go-to-market relationship with them, which is terrific and they can continue to build their practice. They're also a very large customer, so they are leveraging the Lightning platform. They're rolling it out very aggressively. They're getting all the benefits of it, and they are building products on top of our platform. So with a beautiful 360-degree relationship with Accenture, they really served as a model for all of these great systems integrators. I'm going to be with Cap Gemini next week to explore how we accelerate going to market with Cap Gemini. We collaborate with them very regularly about how to drive the market together. I was with the Vice Chairman of PWC a couple of weeks ago talking about our growth strategies together. And our job is really to work very closely with these very trusted advisers to listen to them, to help feed and our ecosystem because is this a huge part of our strategy.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John DiFucci from Jeffries.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John DiFucci from Jeffries.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think this question's for Keith. This has been 2 quarters -- I mean, Salesforce has been putting up numbers better, good numbers for a while. But these last 2 quarters, [indiscernible] really strong, and strong primarily it looks and away from the enter
componenttext: I think this question's for Keith. This has been 2 quarters -- I mean, Salesforce has been putting up numbers better, good numbers for a while. But these last 2 quarters, [indiscernible] really strong, and strong primarily it looks and away from the enterprise. I mean, the SMB seems to have been pretty consistent for quite sometime. But something seems to have changed with the enterprise. The enterprise customer. So Keith, can you talk about what's driving this? What's happening? Are enterprise is just more willing to engage with SaaS and specifically Salesforce? There are some of the processes that you came in. You said -- Marc said it's your third year anniversary coming up. You obviously made some changes and put some things in place. Are they just starting to really sink in right now? And I guess, how sustainable is this? We've seen it now for a couple of quarters.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So John, thanks for the question. So I think a couple of things. Number one, this -- honestly, this has been 17 years in the making. I mean, this is an incredible company with incredible people, an incredible set of core products and customers that I
componenttext: Yes. So John, thanks for the question. So I think a couple of things. Number one, this -- honestly, this has been 17 years in the making. I mean, this is an incredible company with incredible people, an incredible set of core products and customers that I alluded to earlier. And we've been able to gain incredible market share and momentum starting with Marc's vision for cloud computing 17 years ago. So we've been able to capitalize on that, so that's kind of point number one. Point number two is we find ourselves in a world where this convergence of cloud and mobile and social and data science and IoT all coming together, and we kind of lit the match again with Marc's vision 17 years ago and we've been able to reinforce that vision by driving success to our customers. And then over the last -- the third point is over the last 3 years, and successful as the company has always been, we have put a particular emphasis on the enterprise and a focus on expansion in our international markets become and trusted advisers be speaking the language of the customer and the industries and building out our ecosystem kind of how I answered the question about our SI partners before. So all of these things come together. We have built the last, that's been part of the strategy from 17 years back. And I think in the last 3 years, as I said, all these key parts are just augmenting but it's always been a great company with great products and great leadership and incredible employees and customers.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Edward Maguire with CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Edward Maguire with CLSA.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to just ask the question about the source of demand that's driving the acceleration of the platform. Would you characterize that more as a push to find demand where you're building a developer ecosystem and with all of the new features in Lightni
componenttext: I'd like to just ask the question about the source of demand that's driving the acceleration of the platform. Would you characterize that more as a push to find demand where you're building a developer ecosystem and with all of the new features in Lightning, et cetera? Or are you actually starting to see more pool demand as this broad ecosystem of all the accounts works together and attracts more business to the platform?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so -- this is Keith. So this is really a multifaceted thing. Number one, our job is to paint a vision for our customers around driving success and customer engagement. And then we had to back it up by driving that success. And one of the ways we do i
componenttext: Yes, so -- this is Keith. So this is really a multifaceted thing. Number one, our job is to paint a vision for our customers around driving success and customer engagement. And then we had to back it up by driving that success. And one of the ways we do it is with industry-leading products, and that starts with our platform. So that platform is really the secret sauce that allows us to engage, drive this customer engagement level for all of our customer base in the market. So we do create division, if you will, we do create demand, but it also is timing in the market, as I talked about a really between this convergence and the product mobile social, data science and IoT all, together because of customers are seeing the need because the market is ripe for disruption with all these technologies, our platform is amazing, so we're able to deliver on that promise. And then you built at this incredible ecosystem of ISVs who are building on our platform. And they are driving success to our customers by building unique solution. They love the vision of Lightning and the reality of Lightning. So all those things and working together. So it's kind of a push-pull affect. The market has been created and we feel that and it's very cyclical and as a result, you'll see the results in our platform.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I think that's all the time we have for questions today. So I want to thank everyone for joining us on our call for the first quarter. Look forward to updating you on our Q2 results in August. And remember to register for Trailhead VS event her
componenttext: All right. I think that's all the time we have for questions today. So I want to thank everyone for joining us on our call for the first quarter. Look forward to updating you on our Q2 results in August. And remember to register for Trailhead VS event here in San Francisco, June 7 and 8. And of course, gear up for Dreamforce, October 27 [ph]. So look forward to talking to you all in a few months. Thanks so much.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day. My name is Victoria, and I will be your conference operator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Salesforce First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.I would now like to turn the call over to J
componenttext:
Good day. My name is Victoria, and I will be your conference operator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Salesforce First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.
I would now like to turn the call over to John Cummings, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks so much, Victoria. And good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us for our first call -- fiscal first quarter 2017 results conference call. Our first quarter results press release, SEC filings and a replay of today's call can be found on ou
componenttext:
Thanks so much, Victoria. And good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us for our first call -- fiscal first quarter 2017 results conference call. Our first quarter results press release, SEC filings and a replay of today's call can be found on our IR website at www.salesforce.com/investor. And with me today on the call is Marc Benioff, Chairman and CEO; Keith Block, Vice Chairman, President and COO; and Mark Hawkins, CFO.
As a reminder, our commentary today will primarily be in non-GAAP terms. Reconciliations between our GAAP and non-GAAP results and guidance can be found in our earnings press release.
Also, some of our comments today may contain forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks, uncertainties and assumptions. Should any of these materialize or should our assumptions prove to be incorrect, actual company results could differ materially from these forward-looking statements. A description of these risks, uncertainties and assumptions and other factors that could affect our financial results are included in our SEC filings, including our most recent report on Form 10-Q and 10-K.
With that, let me turn the call over to Marc.

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, John, and really excited to be here, really excited for the first quarter. And I -- we got some great people here for the call. We've got Keith Block here, our new Chief Operating Officer. Really excited to have Keith here. We have Mark Hawk
componenttext:
Well, thanks, John, and really excited to be here, really excited for the first quarter. And I -- we got some great people here for the call. We've got Keith Block here, our new Chief Operating Officer. Really excited to have Keith here. We have Mark Hawkins here, our Chief Financial Officer.
And well, you've all seen the press release. We just had an awesome Q1. It's the best Q1 we've ever seen. There are some incredible numbers that you're going to see, including the cash flow number. Revenue for the first quarter, as you saw, grew nearly to $2 billion. That was up 28% in constant currency. That was just above our expectations. Deferred revenue also grew to more than $4 billion, up 32% in constant currency. That was also above our expectations, to see deferred revenue grow with a 3 in front of it at this size and scale.
Dollar value of booked business, on and off the balance sheet at $11.6 billion, up 28% from a year ago. We improved our non-GAAP operating margin, which Mark is going to talk about. And it drove $1 billion in operating cash flow, as I mentioned, but that's 43% from a year ago. It's pretty great.
I'm also thrilled to announce we're raising full year revenue guidance and $80 million raise in the guidance. We feel really excited about that, $8.2 billion at the high end of our range. And our turnout puts us on a clear path. We all can see now that we're going to realize very shortly our $10 billion dream.
We're well positioned for another great year. This is amazing. I think that one of the reasons that we are doing so well is because Oracle and SAP are doing so poorly in the cloud. They just have not been able to make that transformation that we've made, that other companies have made. And we just continue to take market share from them and gain customers at record levels. And you can see that their growth numbers are nothing like we're putting up here as we deliver our first quarter. And it's happening because Salesforce is really the only company totally focused on companies helping to connect with their customers in a whole new way.
We're in the midst of a massive generational shift. A new generation of customers and consumers is clearly emerging. We've been calling them here at Salesforce C-generation customers. Customer generation, consumer generation, these are people who want it now. They want it fast. They want it easy. And they're mobile. They're social. They're always on. And our customers are working to connect with the C-generation in new ways, very exciting.
I mean, this is really part of a huge shift that's happening in computing. We've gone from the first generation of computing, which was very much about systems of record, to the second generation, which was systems of engagement. We talked about that on these calls many times over the last 10 years, and we are clearly moving into this incredible world. It's a system of intelligence that's all yielding these incredible systems of customers or C-generation customers that our customers are connecting to. And that's what we're so excited about.
I know you all want to hear more about those shifts that are going on. Well, I encourage you to come to our World Tour event in London tomorrow. We will have 15,000 people in person, bigger than most companies' user conferences. For us, it's just another visit to a great city in the world. And then next week, we're going to be in New York for a World Tour in New York, which is already sold out. So we'll be excited to see you there.
And in San Francisco on June 7 and 8, we're going to be hosting TrailheaDX, which is our new brand-new developer conference. It also, I believe, has already sold out, but it's going to be an amazing event. We're going to have plenty of opportunities to watch it online. Hard to find venues around the world to host these large events. TrailheaDX, you're going to see the next generation of software's -- Salesforce's software development capability, including our new Lightning systems, component-based development as well as the ability to build one-on-one journeys with customers and a huge focus, a huge focus at TrailheaDX on how to rapidly and easily build mobile applications and really excited to visit with all the Salesforce customers, developers who are coming to TrailheaDX.
Okay. Well, finally, let me tell you, we've got Dreamforce coming on October 4 to 7. I've seen the details. I know the bands that are playing. I know what's going on. I'm not going to give you too much of that yet. I can just tell you it's going to be the biggest and most exciting Dreamforce ever. And it's going to be also just a great year.
And Keith, you're a huge part in making this such a great year. I think we're getting ready to celebrate your third anniversary at Salesforce. Is that right?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right. It's coming up. Absolutely.
componenttext: That's right. It's coming up. Absolutely.

componenttext: When is that going to be so I can have the cupcakes ready?

headline: salesforce.com, inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
